newsitem.title: FRANCE: Striking French bus drivers win retirement at 55.
newsitem.headline: Striking French bus drivers win retirement at 55.

text.p: Striking bus drivers in the southwestern French city of Toulouse have won the right to retire early at 55 and striking fishermen in Corsica have won a hefty state subsidy, officials said on Wednesday.
After an eight-day stoppage, public bus drivers in Toulouse voted late on Tuesday to return to work, the SEMVAT transport authority said.
Employers yielded on most of the strikers' grievances including retirement at 55 instead of 60 and a 35-hour, instead of 38-hour, working week.
Jean-Luc Rueff, spokesman for the Toulouse drivers' branch of the CFDT, France's biggest union, confirmed the strikers had accepted the offer.

In a separate dispute, Corsican fishermen won a 12-million franc ($2.4 million) subsidy from the state to help purchase new boats and re-equip existing vessels. Authorities also granted their demand for cheaper fuel.
The fishermen lifted a week-long blockade of several ports which had paralysed traffic between the French Mediterranean island and the mainland, including passenger ferries.

The latest labour unrest was partly inspired by government concessions to striking truck drivers last month which included a cut in retirement age to 55 from 60, shorter working hours and a wage rise. The truckers had set up some 200 blockades on main roads across the country.
Louis Viannet, leader of the Communist CGT union, cautioned on RTL radio that SNCF state railways may be heading for "a major conflict" as workers fight a management restructuring plan.
"Railway workers are very determined to make themselves heard, not only to defend their status but also to defend a public service and the future of the SNCF as a big national company," Viannet said.
